knowledge: Appendicitis Appendicitis   Appendicitis is inflammation of the appendix. Symptoms commonly include right lower abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and decreased appetite. However, approximately 40% of people do not have these typical symptoms. The pain may also be less severe in some people, particularly those over the age of 65. Other common symptoms include constipation or diarrhea, difficulty passing gas, and a low-grade fever. In young children, the pain may be located around the navel. Symptoms may worsen with time. The cause of appendicitis is not well understood, but it may be due to blockage of the appendix lumen and infection by bacteria. Appendicitis is typically treated with surgery, often requiring removal of the inflamed appendix.

knowledge: Inflammatory Bowel Disease Inflammatory Bowel Disease   Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of inflammatory conditions of the colon and small intestine. Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are the principal types of IBD. Symptoms may include diarrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and fever. Other complications may occur outside the gastrointestinal tract and include anemia, skin rashes, arthritis, inflammation of the eye, and tiredness. The cause of IBD is not well understood, but is believed to involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors. There is no known cure for IBD, but treatment can help control symptoms. Treatment may include medications such as anti-inflammatories and immunosuppressants, as well as surgery in some cases.

knowledge: Colonoscopy Colonoscopy  A colonoscopy is an endoscopic examination of the large bowel and the distal part of the small bowel. It is a key diagnostic and therapeutic tool for detection and removal of cancerous and precancerous lesions in the colon. Colonoscopy can remove polyps as small as one millimeter or less. Once polyps are removed, they can be studied with the aid of a microscope to determine if they are precancerous or not. Colonoscopy is similar to sigmoidoscopy—the difference being related to which parts of the colon each can examine. A colonoscopy allows an examination of the entire colon (1200–1500 mm in length).
